{"uri": "8096537669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:31:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:31:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:31:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://asianlite.com/2024/top-news/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences/", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences - Asian News from UK", "body": "The Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city...reports Asian Lite News\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June, they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nOn Thursday, Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped. They assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\nA senior US official previewing Blinken's trip said that the United States and China were at a \"different place than we were a year ago, when the bilateral relationship was at an historic low point\".\n\n\"We also believe, and we have also clearly demonstrated, that responsibly managing competition does not mean we will pull back from measures to protect US national interests,\" he said.\n\nThe Biden administration's eagerness to engage China stands in stark contrast to its efforts to isolate Russia since its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nAfter initially being pleased that Beijing has not directly supplied weapons to Russia, the United States in recent weeks has accused China of lavishing industrial material and technology on Moscow.", "source": {"uri": "asianlite.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local News for British Asian and Indian Community in London"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8096583540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:59:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:59:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:58:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/world/americas/visiting-blinken-urges-us-china-to-manage-relations-responsibly", "title": "Visiting Blinken urges US, China to manage relations responsibly", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken called on Washington and Beijing to manage their differences and ties \"responsibly\" as he landed in the Chinese capital for a key visit Thursday.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as new U.S. action against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nBlinken headed straight to a closed-door gathering with leading Chinese scholars on Thursday.\n\nOn Friday a full day of talks with China's political leadership is planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived from Shanghai, where the top U.S. diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said U.S. President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people - indeed an obligation to the world - to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of U.S. businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at U.S. airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met U.S. business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit.\"\n\nBlinken, the first U.S. secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of U.S.-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nU.S. officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden - who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump - they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the U.S. Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, {"uri": "8096491093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:04:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:04:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:04:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-ahead-of-talks/articleshow/109592035.cms", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences ahead of talks - Times of India", "body": "BEIJING: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he landed in Beijing for tough talks with the rival power's leaders.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as new US action against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nBlinken headed straight to a closed-door gathering with leading Chinese scholars on Thursday.\n\nOn Friday a full day of talks with China's political leadership is planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived from Shanghai, where the top US diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met US business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit\".\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8096188006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:54:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:54:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:53:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-on-charm-offensive", "title": "Blinken calls for U.S., China to manage differences", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said U.S. President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of U.S. businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June, they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nOn Thursday, Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at U.S. airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nBlinken, the first U.S. secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of U.S.-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nU.S. officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the U.S. Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nU.S. officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, U.S. officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing U.S.-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\n\u00a9 2024 {"uri": "2024-04-335033524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:33:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:33:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:21:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-ahead-of-talks/article_585ce8e9-f59d-590e-ab5a-fe721f7d1883.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences ahead of talks", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he landed in Beijing for tough talks with the rival power's leaders.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as new US action against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nBlinken headed straight to a closed-door gathering with leading Chinese scholars on Thursday.\n\nOn Friday a full day of talks with China's political leadership is planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived from Shanghai, where the top US diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met US business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit\".\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nsct/reb/sn\n\nMore from this section\n\nImagine IT Launches Redesigned Website and Brand Identity to empower Midwest Businesses with Next Generation IT support On Volunteer Recognition Day, the Church of Scientology Nashville Thanks Volunteers Everywhere Whose Help Makes Life Better for Us All Informative Research Adds Mortgage Finance Expert Kurt Raymond, CMB as Senior Vice President", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-04-334659776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:32:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:32:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T02:54:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240425-blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-on-charm-offensive", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences", "body": "Shanghai (AFP) - US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June, they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nOn Thursday, Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nPressing on Russia\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.", "source": city's famous Bund\n\npromenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of\n\nthe Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to\n\n\"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies\n\nafter years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity --\n\nof direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences,\n\nwhich are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world --\n\nto manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed\n\nBlinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the\n\ncity.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of\n\nboth peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power\n\nin China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for New York\n\nUniversity, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel\n\ndocuments, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations\n\nand deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-\n\npeople ties,\" Blinken said.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai,\n\nopened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping\n\narcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and\n\nZhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been\n\nunimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an\n\nemerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit\n\ncontrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach\n\nwhen he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia\n\nwhen he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped\n\nweapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at\n\nMoscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast\n\nquantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks\n\nto focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction\n\nwith the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a\n\ntough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to\n\nconstrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the\n\ndivestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or\n\nface a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young\n\npeople, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United\n\nStates of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise\n\nchampioned a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if\n\nhe returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint\n\nas Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out\n\nusing force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's\n\nelection, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond {"uri": "8096395599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:08:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:08:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:08:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/04/501_373492.html", "title": "In China, Blinken urges fair treatment of American companies", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, left, meets with Shanghai Party Secretary Chen Jining at the Grand Halls, in Shanghai, China, April 25. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardize the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\nThe PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nResponding to the comments later in the day, the spokesperson for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Wang Wenbin, told a regular media conference that \"China has always been carrying out economic and trade cooperation in accordance with the principles of the market.\"\n\n\"We hope that the U.S. side will respect the principle of fair competition, abide by WTO rules and work with China to create favorable conditions for the sound and steady development of China-U.S. economic and trade relations,\" said Wang.\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with business leaders, as well as American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another.\"\n\nU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and NYU Shanghai Vice Chancellor Jeffrey Lehman talks to students at NYU Shanghai, in Shanghai, China, April 25. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nSupport for Russia\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. Those meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defense aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defense industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over the differences. \"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said. Mark Schiefelbein/Pool via REUTERS\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardize the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year, Reuters said.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for US workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\nThe PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nChina has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another\".\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the US, and {"uri": "8096525821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:23:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:23:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:23:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-ahead-of-talks/article_a3736f30-e7ce-5724-ac88-9e04a789a5e6.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences ahead of talks", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he landed in Beijing for tough talks with the rival power's leaders.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as new US action against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nBlinken headed straight to a closed-door gathering with leading Chinese scholars on Thursday.\n\nOn Friday a full day of talks with China's political leadership is planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived from Shanghai, where the top US diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met US business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit\".\n\nMore from this section DR Congo Government Sends Notice to Apple Over 'Illegal Mineral Mining' | Oneindia News Disneyland Celebrates Pixar With Summer-Long Festival That Kicks off This Week EU threatens to suspend TikTok Lite app's 'addictive' rewards - Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nsct/reb/sn", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8096271515", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:51:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:51:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:50:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.zawya.com/en/world/americas/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-yo02pki4", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences", "body": "US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nBlinken, visiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe met US business leaders before leaving for Beijing and said stability was crucial to managing the bilateral relationship responsibly.\n\n\"A big part of that is making sure that the economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit,\" he said.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond precedents.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8096065602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:21:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:21:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:20:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences/article_a3736f30-e7ce-5724-ac88-9e04a789a5e6.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June, they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nOn Thursday, Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nMore from this section Mired in crisis, Boeing reports another loss US conspiracy website Gateway Pundit declares bankruptcy Hornets, Kings among NBA Draft tie-breaker winners\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\nsct/reb/cwl", AFP PHOTO\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed, an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nChen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nBlinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted that the US was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese citizens with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met US business leaders before leaving for the capital Beijing and said stability was crucial to managing the bilateral relationship responsibly.\n\n\"A big part of that is making sure that the economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit,\" he said.\n\nPressing on RussiaBlinken, the first US secretary of state to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit on Wednesday night at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergey Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough reelection fight against his predecessor Donald Trump in November -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the US of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUS officials also say Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates new leader Lai Ching-te next month.\n\nChina claims the self-ruling, democratic island as its own and has not ruled out using force to retake it.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's {"uri": "8096027524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:48:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:48:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:48:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/in-china-blinken-urges-fair-treatment-of-american-companies/article_73951255-9259-57d1-a244-5c1e71b064a2.html", "title": "In China, Blinken urges fair treatment of American companies", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is greeted by U.S. Ambassador to the People's Republic of China R. Nicholas Burns on his arrival in Shanghai, China, April 24, 2024. Blinken is starting three days of talks with senior Chinese officials in Shanghai and Beijing this week with U.S.-China ties at a critical point over numerous global disputes. Mark Schiefelbein/Pool via REUTERS\n\nBy Simon Lewis\n\nSHANGHAI (Reuters) -U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\nThe PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nChina has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another\".\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. Those meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over the differences. \"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said.\n\n(Reporting by Simon Lewis; Writing by Antoni Slodkowski; Editing by Christopher Cushing and Miral Fahmy)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8095945712", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:28:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:28:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T03:27:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/blinken-meets-top-shanghai-official-as-he-kicks-off-a-tough-china-trip/article_73951255-9259-57d1-a244-5c1e71b064a2.html", "title": "Blinken meets top Shanghai official as he kicks off a tough China trip", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is greeted by U.S. Ambassador to the People's Republic of China R. Nicholas Burns on his arrival in Shanghai, China, April 24, 2024. Blinken is starting three days of talks with senior Chinese officials in Shanghai and Beijing this week with U.S.-China ties at a critical point over numerous global disputes. Mark Schiefelbein/Pool via REUTERS\n\nBy Simon Lewis\n\nSHANGHAI (Reuters) -U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken met China's top official in Shanghai on Thursday as ties between Washington and Beijing stabilise, hoping to resolve on his trip a raft of issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's visit is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have made little headway on curbing China's supply of chemicals used to make fentanyl, the South China Sea remains a flashpoint, and strains are growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai, as they started their meeting.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nIn addition to local officials, Blinken will meet with business leaders and students before heading to Beijing for talks on Friday with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and a likely meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nThese meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over unresolved issues.\n\n\"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said.\n\n(Reporting by Simon Lewis; Writing by Antoni Slodkowski; Editing by Christopher Cushing and Miral Fahmy)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/worldbiz/usa/china-blinken-urges-fair-treatment-american-companies-835946", "title": "In China, Blinken urges fair treatment of American companies", "body": "US Secretary of State Antony Blinken today (25 April) called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\nThe PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nChina has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another\".\n\nSupport for Russia\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. Those meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over the differences. \"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by
