{"uri": "8097177599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:24:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-ahead-of-talks/article68106606.ece", "title": "Blinken calls for U.S., China to manage differences ahead of talks", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken called on Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he landed in Beijing for tough talks with the rival power's leaders.\n\nMr. Blinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as new U.S. action against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nMr. Blinken headed straight to a closed-door gathering with leading Chinese scholars on Thursday.\n\nOn Friday a full day of talks with China's political leadership is planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nMr. Blinken arrived from Shanghai, where the top U.S. diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Mr. Blinken said U.S. President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Mr. Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Mr. Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of U.S. businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Mr. Chen told him.\n\nMr. Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at U.S. airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Mr. Blinken said.\n\nHe also met U.S. business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit\".\n\nPressing on Russia\n\nMr. Blinken, the first U.S. Secretary of State to visit Shanghai in 14 years, opened his visit on Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns before going to watch a basketball match between the Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of U.S.-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nMr. Blinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nThe next leg of Mr. Blinken's trip is set to be far less relaxing when he meets top cadres in Beijing.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Mr. Blinken to meet Mr. Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nAmong the many sticky issues Mr. Blinken is expected to raise in Beijing are concerns about China's relationship with Russia.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nU.S. officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Mr. Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the U.S. Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nMr. Biden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Mr. Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": He plans to meet with students and business leaders before traveling to Beijing for contentious discussions with Chinese officials. Blinken's visit comes after Biden signed a foreign aid package that includes funds to counter China's influence in Taiwan and the South China Sea, and seeks to force TikTok's sale. Despite tensions, both sides acknowledge the importance of direct engagement and responsible management of the relationship. Blinken also attended a basketball game in Shanghai, where the home team lost in a close match.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken opened his first full day of meetings in China on Thursday by talking with local government officials in Shanghai.\n\nBlinken discussed local and regional issues with Chen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai. He also planned to speak to students and business leaders before heading to Beijing by train for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger the Chinese, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against U.S. assistance to Taiwan, the self-governing island that it regards as a renegade province, and immediately condemned the move as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, a similar visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\" Chen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\" \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls, with the home team losing in the last seconds in 121-120 nailbiter.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8096332680", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:30:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:30:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:29:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/china/china-blinken-urges-fair-treatment-american-companies", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "SHANGHAI -- US Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for US workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\nThe PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nChina has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose co-operation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another\".\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. Those meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included US$8 billion (S$11 billion) to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and US$61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the US if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, US officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging US and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the US, and the US side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over the differences. \"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said.", "source": {"uri": "asiaone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AsiaOne"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-04-334702566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:29:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:29:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences/article_585ce8e9-f59d-590e-ab5a-fe721f7d1883.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June, they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nOn Thursday, Blinken also met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students.\n\nBeijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to watch a basketball game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls, staying until the end of the nail-biting play-off.\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- they say serve to constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China, with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize it.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nThey assessed that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\nsct/reb/cwl\n\nMore from this section\n\nDark Matter and Total Expert partner to boost lender revenue through best-in-class mortgage automation and customer engagement California IVF He also planned to speak to students and business leaders before heading to Beijing by train for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger the Chinese, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against U.S. assistance to Taiwan, the self-governing island that it regards as a renegade province, and immediately condemned the move as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, a similar visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n''I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,'' Blinken told Chen.\n\n''We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,'' he said. countries' relationship.''\n\n''Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity'' he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped {"uri": "8096685138", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:03:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:03:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:02:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/04/25/us-china-relations-blinkens-visit-in-shanghai-highlights-deep-seated-trade-security-concerns/", "title": "US-China relations: Blinken's visit in Shanghai highlights deep-seated trade, security concerns | Matthew Lee | AP Diplomatic Writer", "body": "SHANGHAI -- US Secretary of State Antony Blinken raised what the US describes as unfair Chinese trade practices during his first full day of meetings in China on Thursday with local government officials in the financial hub of Shanghai.\n\nBlinken met with the city's top official, Communist Party Secretary Chen Jining, and \"raised concerns about (Chinese) trade policies and non-market economic practices,\" the State Department said in a statement.\n\nIt said he stressed that the United States seeks healthy economic competition with China and \"a level playing field for US workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\n\"The two sides reaffirmed the importance of ties between the people of the United States and (China), including the expansion of exchanges between students, scholars, and business,\" it said.\n\nChina's multibillion-dollar trade surplus with the US along with accusations of intellectual property theft and other practices seen as discriminating against US businesses in China have long been a source of friction in relations.\n\nChina, for its part, has objected strongly to US accusations of human rights abuses and Washington's support for Taiwan, the self-governing island that Beijing considers its own territory and warns could be annexed by force.\n\nBlinken also spoke with students and business leaders before flying to Beijing for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and possibly President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before US President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger Beijing, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against US assistance to Taiwan and immediately condemned the aid as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Xi, a visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the US and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\"\n\nChen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\"\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity,\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai, a city of skyscrapers, ports and more than 25 million people that is a magnet for commercially ambitious young people from China and abroad.\n\nMost recently, the US has raised concerns that potential overcapacity in Chinese industries -- such as electric vehicles, steel and solar panels -- might crowd out US and other foreign manufacturers.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls, with the home team losing in the last seconds in a 121-120 nailbiter.\n\nWith the US presidential race heating up, it's unclear what ramifications a victory for either Biden or former President Donald Trump might have for relations. But Trump could deepen a trade war he started during his first term. {"uri": "8096011810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:34:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:34:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/3/215717/Blinken-meets-top-Shanghai-official-as-he-kicks-off-a-tough-China-trip", "title": "Blinken meets top Shanghai official as he kicks off a tough China trip", "body": "U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken met China's top official in Shanghai on Thursday as ties between Washington and Beijing stabilise, hoping to resolve on his trip a raft of issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's visit is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have made little headway on curbing China's supply of chemicals used to make fentanyl, the South China Sea remains a flashpoint, and strains are growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai, as they started their meeting.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nIn addition to local officials, Blinken will meet with business leaders and students before heading to Beijing for talks on Friday with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and a likely meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nThese meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over unresolved issues.\n\n\"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said.", "source": {"uri": "thestandard.com.hk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8095915085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "02:57:39", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T02:57:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T02:57:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/news/world/a/2189656.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences on charm offensive", "body": "US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a reception room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff outside on wooden chairs in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to a basketball stadium, watching a nail-biting play-off game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls until the end.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries previously speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe that China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- that could constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize Taiwan.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nTheir assessment was that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.", "source": {"uri": "8097323469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "19:27:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T19:27:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T19:23:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news/section/11/262341/Blinken-on-charm-offensive-ahead-of-tough-talks", "title": "Blinken on charm offensive ahead of tough talks", "body": "US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he landed in Beijing for tough talks with the rival power's leaders.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a range of thorny issues, including Chinese support for Russia and its treatment of Taiwan, with China likely to raise trade concerns such as the new bill against popular social media app TikTok.\n\nA full day of talks with China's political leadership today has been planned, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although a meeting was announced at the last minute during his previous visit in June.\n\nBlinken arrived yesterday from Shanghai, where the top US diplomat attempted a charm offensive that saw him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nHis aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov's gruffer approach when he visited China this month.\n\nBlinken said US President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, laying out our differences and working through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation to our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken, partly in English, and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen said.\n\nBlinken met students at the Shanghai campus of New York University, where he voiced hope for more Americans to study in China.\n\nHe insisted that the United States was committed to welcoming Chinese students. Beijing has repeatedly alleged that Chinese nationals with valid travel documents, including students, have been subject to aggressive interrogations and deportations at US airports.\n\n\"President Biden and President Xi are determined to strengthen our people-to-people ties,\" Blinken said.\n\nHe also met US business leaders, telling them that the two countries needed to make sure the \"economic relationship is working in the ways that it should work to mutual benefit.\"", "source": {"uri": "thestandard.com.hk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Standard"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-04-334847918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:59:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:59:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:52:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/blinken-raises-chinese-trade-practices-in-meetings-with-officials-in-the-financial-hub-of-shanghai/article_159c2ff8-eb84-596b-ad84-493e2e69bb3b.html", "title": "Blinken raises Chinese trade practices in meetings with officials in the financial hub of Shanghai", "body": "SHANGHAI (AP) -- U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken raised what the U.S. describes as unfair Chinese trade practices during his first full day of meetings in China on Thursday with local government officials in the financial hub of Shanghai.\n\nBlinken met with the city's top official, Communist Party Secretary Chen Jining, and \"raised concerns about (Chinese) trade policies and non-market economic practices,\" the State Department said in a statement.\n\nIt said he stressed that the United States seeks healthy economic competition with China and \"a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\n\"The two sides reaffirmed the importance of ties between the people of the United States and (China), including the expansion of exchanges between students, scholars, and business,\" it said.\n\nChina's multibillion-dollar trade surplus with the U.S. along with accusations of intellectual property theft and other practices seen as discriminating against U.S. businesses in China have long been a source of friction in relations.\n\nChina, for its part, has objected strongly to U.S. accusations of human rights abuses and Washington's support for Taiwan, the self-governing island that Beijing considers its own territory and warns could be annexed by force.\n\nBlinken also spoke with students and business leaders before flying to Beijing for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and possibly President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before U.S. President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger Beijing, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against U.S. assistance to Taiwan and immediately condemned the aid as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Xi, a visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\"\n\nChen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\"\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity,\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai, a city of skyscrapers, ports and more than 25 million people that is a magnet for commercially ambitious young people from China and abroad.\n\nMost recently, the U.S. has raised concerns that potential overcapacity in Chinese industries -- such as electric vehicles, steel and solar panels -- might crowd out U.S. and other foreign manufacturers.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls, with the home team losing in the last seconds in a 121-120 nailbiter.\n\nWith the U.S. presidential race heating up, it's unclear what ramifications a victory for either Biden or former President Donald Trump might have for relations. But Trump could deepen a trade war he started during his first term. His tough rhetoric on China and isolationist approach to foreign policy could ramp up uncertainties.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, {"uri": "8096325766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:26:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:26:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:25:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2917163-blinken-discusses-chinese-trade-practices-in-meetings-with-shanghai-officials", "title": "Blinken discusses Chinese trade practices in meetings with Shanghai officials | Law-Order", "body": "US Secretary Blinken met with Shanghai officials, raising concerns about unfair Chinese trade practices. Despite tensions over trade, intellectual property theft, and human rights, both sides emphasized the importance of people-to-people ties. Blinken's visit to Beijing is expected to be contentious, as the US has expressed concerns about Chinese aggression toward Taiwan and is supporting a $95 billion aid package that may provoke Beijing. However, the Biden-Xi call and Blinken's engagement indicate a willingness to address differences. Shanghai's top official stressed the need for cooperation and managing the relationship responsibly.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken raised what the US describes as unfair Chinese trade practices during his first full day of meetings in China on Thursday with local government officials in the financial hub of Shanghai.\n\nBlinken met with the city's top official, Communist Party Secretary Chen Jining, and \"raised concerns about (Chinese) trade policies and non-market economic practices,'' the State Department said in a statement.\n\nIt said he stressed that the United States seeks healthy economic competition with China and ''a level playing field for US workers and firms operating in China.\" \"The two sides reaffirmed the importance of ties between the people of the United States and (China), including the expansion of exchanges between students, scholars, and business,\" it said.\n\nChina's multibillion-dollar trade surplus with the US along with accusations of intellectual property theft and other practices seen as discriminating against US businesses in China have long been a source of friction in relations.\n\nChina, for its part, has objected strongly to US accusations of human rights abuses and Washington's support for Taiwan, the self-governing island that Beijing considers its own territory and warns could be annexed by force.\n\nBlinken also spoke with students and business leaders before flying to Beijing for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and possibly President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before US President Joe Biden signed a USD 95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger Beijing, including USD 8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against US assistance to Taiwan and immediately condemned the aid as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Xi, a visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the US and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\" Chen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\" \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity,\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai, a city of skyscrapers, ports and more than 25 million people that is a magnet for commercially ambitious young people from China and abroad.\n\nMost recently, the US has raised concerns that potential overcapacity in Chinese industries -- such as electric vehicles, steel and solar panels -- might crowd out US and other foreign manufacturers.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls, with the home team losing in the last seconds in a 121-120 nailbiter.\n\nWith the US presidential race heating up, it's unclear what ramifications a victory for either Biden or former President Donald Trump might have for relations. But Trump could deepen a trade war he started during his first term. His tough rhetoric on China and isolationist approach to foreign policy could ramp up uncertainties.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated He also planned to speak to students and business leaders before flying to Beijing for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger the Chinese, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against U.S. assistance to Taiwan, the self-governing island that it regards as a renegade province, and immediately condemned the move as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip -- shortly after a conversation between Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, a similar visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs -- is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\"\n\nChen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\"\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang {"uri": "8097152563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:05:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:05:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:05:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/politics/blinken-calls-on-the-us-and-china-to-manage-their-differences-responsibly/20240425190000199335.html", "title": "Blinken calls on the US and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\"", "body": "US Chief of State Antony Blinken on Thursday defended the need to manage differences between the United States and China \"responsibly\" as he arrived in Beijing to discuss those differences with the Chinese authorities.\n\n\"We have an obligation to our people - and indeed to the world - to manage relations between our two countries in a responsible way,\" Blinken said on his second trip to China in less than a year.\n\nBlinken is expected to address a number of complex issues, including China's support for Russia and its relationship with Taiwan, while Beijing could raise trade concerns, including measures against the popular video app TikTok.\n\nUpon arriving in Beijing, the secretary of state immediately went to a private meeting with leading Chinese academics.\n\nOn Friday, he will have meetings all day with Chinese political leaders, including a possible meeting with President Xi Jinping, which has not been announced by local officials.\n\n\"I think it's important to stress the value - rather the necessity - of talking to each other, exposing our differences, which are real, seeking to resolve them,\" Blinken said in Shanghai, where he began his visit to China on Wednesday.\n\nThere he met with the local head of the Chinese Communist Party, Chen Jining, and attended a basketball game between two teams with American players on their squads.\n\nChen welcomed Blinken, speaking at times in English, and noted the importance of US companies in the city, China's financial capital.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the welfare of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen said.\n\nBlinken also met in Shanghai with students at the local campus of New York University and with business leaders, to whom he said the two countries must ensure that \"the economic relationship works in a way that is mutually beneficial\".\n\nBut the more complex issues could arise in Beijing, where Blinken must call for restraint toward Taiwan, which is preparing to inaugurate a new president in May, and raise US concerns about Chinese trade practices, a key issue for President Joe Biden in an election year.\n\nThe secretary of state hopes to further defuse tensions between the world's two largest economies, which have clearly been on a downward trend since his June visit and the meeting between Presidents Biden and Xi in November.\n\nUS officials have indicated that China appears more open to Western concerns.\n\nHowever, China has expressed anger at a number of actions by the Biden administration that it believes are hurting the Chinese economy.\n\nCongress recently passed a bill that would force the Chinese owners of TikTok to sell the platform to avoid being banned in the US.\n\nBiden supported the bill on the grounds that TikTok, which is popular among young people, poses security and privacy risks, but China claims it is unfair economic coercion.\n\nThe US leader has also advocated steep tariff increases against China if he is re-elected in November.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-335065953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:59:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:59:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:29:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/apr/25/blinken-in-china-brings-up-unfair-trade-practices-/", "title": "Blinken raises Chinese trade practices in meetings with officials in the financial hub of Shanghai", "body": "SHANGHAI (AP) -- U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken raised what the U.S. describes as unfair Chinese trade practices during his first full day of meetings in China on Thursday with local government officials in the financial hub of Shanghai.\n\nBlinken met with the city's top official, Communist Party Secretary Chen Jining, and \"raised concerns about (Chinese) trade policies and non-market economic practices,\" the State Department said in a statement.\n\nIt said he stressed that the United States seeks healthy economic competition with China and \"a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\"\n\n\"The two sides reaffirmed the importance of ties between the people of the United States and (China), including the expansion of exchanges between students, scholars, and business,\" it said.\n\nChina's multibillion-dollar trade surplus with the U.S. along with accusations of intellectual property theft and other practices seen as discriminating against U.S. businesses in China have long been a source of friction in relations.\n\nChina, for its part, has objected strongly to U.S. accusations of human rights abuses and Washington's support for Taiwan, the self-governing island that Beijing considers its own territory and warns could be annexed by force.\n\nAsked about Blinken's comments, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin said China has \"always conducted economic and trade cooperation in accordance with market principles, firmly supported the multilateral trading system, and fully complied with the rules of the World Trade Organization.\"\n\n\"We hope the U.S. will also earnestly respect the principle of fair competition, abide by the WTO rules, and work with China to create favorable conditions for the sound and stable development of China-U.S. economic and trade relations,\" Wang told reporters at a daily briefing.\n\nBlinken also spoke with students and business leaders before flying to Beijing for what are expected to be contentious talks with national officials, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and possibly President Xi Jinping.\n\nBlinken arrived in Shanghai on Wednesday shortly before U.S. President Joe Biden signed a $95 billion foreign aid package that has several elements likely to anger Beijing, including $8 billion to counter China's growing aggressiveness toward Taiwan and in the South China Sea. It also seeks to force TikTok's China-based parent company to sell the social media platform.\n\nChina has railed against U.S. assistance to Taiwan and immediately condemned the aid as a dangerous provocation. It also strongly opposes efforts to force TikTok's sale.\n\nStill, the fact that Blinken made the trip - shortly after a conversation between Biden and Xi, a visit to China by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and a call between the U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs - is a sign the two sides are at least willing to discuss their differences.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen, according to the State Department statement.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people, indeed an obligation to the world, to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly,\" he said. \"That is the obligation we have, and one that we take very seriously.\"\n\nChen agreed with that sentiment and said the recent Biden-Xi call had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship.\"\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity,\" he said.\n\nChen added that he hoped Blinken was able to get a \"deep impression and understanding\" of Shanghai, a city of skyscrapers, ports and more than 25 million people that is a magnet for commercially ambitious young people from China and abroad.\n\nMost recently, the U.S. has raised concerns that potential overcapacity in Chinese industries - such as electric vehicles, steel and solar panels - might crowd out U.S. and other foreign manufacturers.\n\nShortly after arriving, Blinken attended a Chinese basketball playoff game between the local Shanghai Sharks and the Zhejiang Golden Bulls, with the home team losing in the last seconds in a 121-120 nailbiter.\n\nWith the U.S. presidential race heating up, it's unclear what ramifications a victory for either Biden or former President Donald Trump might have for relations. But Trump could deepen a trade war he started during his first term. His tough rhetoric on China and isolationist approach to foreign policy could ramp up uncertainties.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-on-charm-offensive/article_a3736f30-e7ce-5724-ac88-9e04a789a5e6.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences on charm offensive", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a reception room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff outside on wooden chairs in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to a basketball stadium, watching a nail-biting play-off game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls until the end.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries previously speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nMore from this section 'Neutrality' issues found at UN agency for Palestinians, but no terrorism proof Bleach blond? Biden mocks Trump's hair in personal barb Brazil judge drops case on Bolsonaro stay in Hungarian embassy\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe that China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- that could constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize Taiwan.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nTheir assessment was that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\nsct/reb/tym", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "shaun_tandon@reformer.com", "name": "Shaun Tandon", "type": China has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative.\n\nU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday called on China to provide a level playing field for American businesses as he began a visit aimed at resolving a raft of contentious issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship. Blinken's trip is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have been increasingly at odds over how American companies operate in China, Chinese exports and manufacturing capacity, and strains are also growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that at a meeting with China's top official in Shanghai, Chen Jining, Blinken raised concerns about China's \"trade policies and non-market economic practices.\"\n\nBlinken also \"stressed that the United States seeks a healthy economic competition with the PRC and a level playing field for U.S. workers and firms operating in China.\" The PRC, or People's Republic of China, is the country's official name.\n\nChina has dismissed as groundless criticism that its manufacturing capacity is excessive, adding that its industries, ranging from electric vehicles to solar panels, are competitive and innovative. Chen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries had helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nWhile in Shanghai, Blinken also spoke with American and Chinese students at New York University's local campus, where he said intercultural interactions were \"the best way to make sure that we start by hopefully understanding one another\". SUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will head to Beijing on Friday for talks with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and possibly President Xi Jinping. Those meetings could be fraught. Just as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year. Blinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security. State-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said. Other state media also highlighted the tensions over the differences. \"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8095909535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "02:50:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T02:50:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T02:50:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/1-blinken-meets-top-shanghai-024005152.html", "title": "UPDATE 1-Blinken meets top Shanghai official as he kicks off a tough China trip", "body": "(Adds comments by officials, China Daily editorials)\n\nBy Simon Lewis\n\nSHANGHAI, April 25 (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken met China's top official in Shanghai on Thursday as ties between Washington and Beijing stabilise, hoping to resolve on his trip a raft of issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's visit is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have made little headway on curbing China's supply of chemicals used to make fentanyl, the South China Sea remains a flashpoint, and strains are growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai, as they started their meeting.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nIn addition to local officials, Blinken will meet with business leaders and students before heading to Beijing for talks on Friday with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and a likely meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nThese meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over unresolved issues.\n\n\"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said. {"uri": "8095932758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:15:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:15:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T03:14:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13347887/Blinken-meets-Shanghai-official-kicks-tough-China-trip.html", "title": "Blinken meets top Shanghai official as he kicks off a tough China trip", "body": "By Simon Lewis\n\nSHANGHAI, April 25 (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken met China's top official in Shanghai on Thursday as ties between Washington and Beijing stabilise, hoping to resolve on his trip a raft of issues that could jeopardise the newly repaired relationship.\n\nBlinken's visit is the latest high-level contact between the two nations that, along with working groups on issues from global trade to military communication, have tempered the public acrimony that drove relations to historic lows early last year.\n\nBut Washington and Beijing have made little headway on curbing China's supply of chemicals used to make fentanyl, the South China Sea remains a flashpoint, and strains are growing over Beijing's backing of Russia in its war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value - in fact, the necessity - of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken told Chen Jining, the Chinese Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai, as they started their meeting.\n\nChen said through translators that the recent call between the leaders of both countries helped the \"stable and healthy development of our two countries' relationship\", adding: \"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries, and the future of humanity.\"\n\nIn addition to local officials, Blinken will meet with business leaders and students before heading to Beijing for talks on Friday with his counterpart, Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and a likely meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nThese meetings could be fraught.\n\nJust as Blinken landed in Shanghai, President Joe Biden signed a rare bipartisan bill that included $8 billion to counter China's military might, as well as billions in defence aid for Taiwan and $61 billion in aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden also signed a separate bill tied to the aid legislation that bans TikTok in the U.S. if its owner, the Chinese tech firm ByteDance, fails to divest the popular short video app over the next nine months to a year.\n\nSUPPORT FOR RUSSIA\n\nBlinken will press China to stop its firms from retooling and resupplying Russia's defence industrial base. Moscow invaded Ukraine days after agreeing a \"no limits\" partnership with Beijing, and while China has steered clear of providing arms, U.S. officials warn Chinese companies are sending dual-use technology that helps Russia's war effort.\n\nWithout providing details, a senior State Department official told reporters that Washington was prepared to \"take steps\" against Chinese firms it believes are damaging U.S. and European security.\n\nState-run China Daily said in an editorial that there was \"a huge question mark over what the discussions between Blinken and his hosts can yield\" and that both sides \"have been largely talking past each other.\"\n\n\"On the conflict in Ukraine, the world can see it clearly that the Ukraine issue is not an issue between China and the U.S., and the U.S. side should not turn it into one,\" it said.\n\nOther state media also highlighted the tensions over unresolved issues.\n\n\"Plenty of animosity remains, primarily fuelled by Washington's adherence to a zero-sum mindset and framing China as a threat,\" a commentary in state-run Xinhua news agency said. {"uri": "2024-04-334619940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "03:34:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T03:34:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T02:52:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/blinken-calls-for-us-china-to-manage-differences-on-charm-offensive/article_585ce8e9-f59d-590e-ab5a-fe721f7d1883.html", "title": "Blinken calls for US, China to manage differences on charm offensive", "body": "Blinken watched a nail-biting play-off match between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken called Thursday on the United States and China to manage their differences \"responsibly\" as he went on a charm offensive ahead of expected tough talks.\n\nA day before meeting Beijing's top brass to tackle thorny issues including Russia, Taiwan and trade, Blinken's visit to Shanghai has seen him sample local food, watch a basketball game and stroll along the city's famous Bund promenade.\n\nVisiting the local Communist Party leader in a reception room with sweeping views of the Shanghai skyline, Blinken said President Joe Biden was committed to \"direct and sustained\" dialogue between the world's two largest economies after years of mounting tension.\n\n\"I think it's important to underscore the value -- in fact, the necessity -- of direct engagement, of speaking to each other, laying out our differences, which are real, seeking to work through them,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"We have an obligation for our people -- indeed an obligation to the world -- to manage the relationship between our two countries responsibly.\"\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party secretary for Shanghai, Chen Jining, welcomed Blinken partly in English and spoke of the importance of US businesses to the city.\n\n\"Whether we choose cooperation or confrontation affects the well-being of both peoples, both countries and the future of humanity,\" Chen told him.\n\nThe country's financial capital, Shanghai is often a stepping stone to power in China, with President Xi Jinping previously serving briefly in the city.\n\nChina has not announced plans for Blinken to meet Xi, although on Blinken's last visit in June they saw each other in a meeting announced at the last minute.\n\nBlinken, the first US secretary of state in 14 years to visit Shanghai, opened his visit Wednesday evening at a restaurant serving steamed buns.\n\nSporting a suit without a tie, he ate with his senior staff outside on wooden chairs in a shopping arcade as curious onlookers snapped pictures.\n\nBlinken then went to a basketball stadium, watching a nail-biting play-off game between the Shanghai Sharks and Zhejiang Golden Bulls until the end.\n\n- Pressing on Russia -\n\nSuch softer diplomacy, once a staple of US-China relations, would have been unimaginable until recently, with hawks in both countries previously speaking of an emerging new Cold War.\n\nBlinken's aides hope his smiling persona at public events draws an implicit contrast to his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov and his gruffer approach when he visited China earlier this month.\n\nBlinken is expected to raise concerns about China's relationship with Russia when he meets the leadership in Beijing.\n\nAlthough US officials were initially pleased that Beijing has not shipped weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine, they now say that China's alarm at Moscow's setbacks on the battlefield has prompted it to export vast quantities of industrial supplies to Russia.\n\nUS officials believe that China is more receptive to Western concerns as it seeks to focus on managing economic headwinds at home and wants to avoid friction with the West.\n\nBut China is also furious about a series of moves by Biden -- who is facing a tough re-election fight in November against Donald Trump -- that could constrain the Chinese economy.\n\nMost recently, the US Congress approved legislation that would force the divestment of blockbuster social media app TikTok from its Chinese owners or face a ban in the world's largest economy.\n\nBiden supports the legislation, arguing that TikTok, popular among young people, poses security and privacy concerns. China has accused the United States of unfair economic coercion.\n\nUnusually, Trump has distanced himself from a TikTok ban. He has otherwise championed a tough line on China with vows to raise tariffs drastically if he returns to office.\n\nUS officials also say that Blinken will encourage China to act with restraint as Taiwan inaugurates a new president next month.\n\nChina claims the self-governing democracy as its own and has not ruled out using force to seize Taiwan.\n\nPrivately, US officials were relieved by China's approach during Taiwan's election, believing that easing US-China tensions helped.\n\nTheir assessment was that Beijing's assertive military moves did not go beyond past precedent.\n\nsct/reb/tym\n\nMore from this section\n\nTabloid publisher says he pledged to be Trump campaign's 'eyes and ears' during 2016 race Concordia Announces Strategic Partnership with the Fund
